description.narrative:
Innocenti, the research institute of UNICEF has applied for 21MSEK to implement Transfer Project phase 2, 2018-2020. The project shall contribute to longitudinal quantitative and qualitatve evaluations of the effects of social protection systems with cash transfers in government led programs for social cash transfers. The project shall especially evaluate new initiatives to strengthen the effects of social cash transfer through complementary contributions, so called 'Cash Plus', and contribute to evaluation of cash support in humanitarian aid.
The Transfer project undertakes analysis within countries but also regional analysis with the purpose of drawing thematic conclusions and to draw conclusions of differences in implementation and effects of different types of social cash transfer programs in the region.
The project also aims to contribute to learning and exchange between policy-makers, implementing agencies, researchers and civil society through seminars, web-based information, publication of data and open-source publications. The Transfer project is focused on strengthening monitoring and evaluation of government led programmes for social cash transfer and through evidence-based information strengthen programme design and policy dialogue. The research is also expected to contribute to knowledge about the link between social protection and cash transfers in humanitarian contexts. The project also aims to strengthen research capacity in Africa for studying and evaluating social protection systems. The Transfer project is implemented in coperation with governments, implementing agencies responsible for social protection programmes, and in cooperation with local researchers with the aim to strengthen ownership and knowledge locally. The total budget of the project is 4,385,741 USD of which Sida contributes with 21 million SEK (approximately 2,617,662 USD).

UNICEFs forskningsinstitut Innocenti har ansökt om 21 miljoner SEK för att genomföra Transfer Project 2. Projektet ska bidra till långsiktiga kvantitativa och kvalitativa utvärderingar av effekterna av sociala trygghetssystem med kontantstöd i statliga program för sociala kontantstöd. Projektet ska särskilt utvärdera nya initiativ för att stärka effekterna av sociala kontantstöd genom kompletterande insatser, så kallat "Cash Plus", samt bidra till utvärdering av kontantstöd inom humanitärt bistånd.
Transfer projektet gör analys inom länder men gör även regionala analyser i syfte att dra tematiska slutsatser och för att dra slutsatser om skillnader i genomförande och effekter av olika sociala kontantstödsprogram i regionen.
Projektet syftar dessutom till att bidra till lärande och utbyte mellan beslutsfattare, genomförare, forskare och civila samhället genom seminarier, webb-baserad information, publicering av data och öppet tillgängliga publikationer.
Transfer projektet är inriktat på att stärka uppföljning och utvärdering av statliga ledda program för sociala trygghetssystem och bidra till att genom evidensbaserad kunskap stärka programmering och policydialog om programmens genomförande. Forskningen förväntas också bidra till att stärka kunskap om länken mellan social trygghet och kontantstöd i humanitärt bistånd. Transfer projektet genomförs i samarbete med regeringar, genomförande myndigheter som ansvarar för program för social trygghet samt i samarbete med lokala forskare, i syfte att stärka ägarskap och kunskap lokalt. Projektet förväntas också stärka Sidas samarbete inom sociala trygghetssystem genom att dialog om inriktning och genomförande kan baseras på evidens från kvalitativ forskning och utvärdering.
Projektets totala budget är 4,385,741 USD varav Sida bidrar med 21 miljoner SEK (cirka 2,617,662 USD).

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

tag.narrative: 1.3 - Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
1.3 - Införa nationellt lämpliga system och åtgärder för socialt skydd för alla, inklusive grundskydd, och senast 2030 säkerställa att de omfattar en väsentlig andel av de fattiga och de utsatta.
10.4 - Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.
10.4 - Besluta om politik, särskilt finans-, löne- och socialskyddspolitik, och successivt uppnå ökad jämlikhet.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Conclusion on performance is prepared based on the Annual Report including a financial statement for 2019 received in March 2020, an Annual meeting, which was held as a virtuel meeting, as a planned meeting between Sida and new staff at Innocenti could not be implemented due to the outbreak of Covid-19. Sida received an updated risk assessment in May 2020 where Innocenti presented a new risk analyses to the project, for example challenges related to new travel restrictions, that all contacts with research fellows have to be managed at distance and finaly that there was a risk that some key activities, like collection of data, could be delayed because of the pandemic. In the autumn Sida and Innocenti have had follow up discussions on the implementation to date and plans for future cooperation. In 2019 and 2020 the Transfer project has continued to provide evidence to national governments on Social Cash Transfers and to stakeholders within the field of social protection with cash transfers. The Transfer project has synthesized cross-country findings; continued ongoing research projects and initiated new research on cash plus (systems linkages); research has also been initiated in the area of social protection in contexts of fragility and forced displacement. The Transfer Project has undertaken research and supported capacity building and dissemination of evidence according to plan or exceeding targets during 2019 and with some delays in 2020. The research is of high quality and internationally recognised as providing important knowledge and evidence on the effects of social protection and cash transfers. This evidence is important for governments in partner countries that are expanding social protection systems which require substantial and long-term investments. The Transfer project also has direct linkages to Sida-supported projects in social protection. Direct TA in the form of impact evaluation studies were provided in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia, Jordan, Malawi, Mozambique and Tanzania. This included the new program for social protection in Burkina Faso (UNICEF contribution no 10800) which received support to set up an impact evaluation that can follow up the project implementation, as well as guidance on project design features. The programme in Burkina Faso is linking social protection to nutrition which is a sector where information and evidence is lacking if and how social protection can contribute to positive results, which makes the cooperation with Innocenti, the transfer project highly important. Another example is Ethiopia (UNICEF contribution no 10698) where a baseline evaluation was undertaken with beneficiaries in the pilot project sites. A final example is Tanzania where two reports were published in 2020 "Adolecent Cash Plus Midline Report" with new information on cash and young people and the recent "Participant Experiences with Tanzania's Productive Safety Net 2019 Payment Delays". The latter gave important insights on how the unplanned gap between PSSN I and II, effected people living in poverty in a negative way and the importance to strengthen the rights perspective for example through grievance mechanisms even more in the design of social protection interventions. This information inspired and improved Sida's appraisal of additional support to PSSN II (Contribution no 14350). The collaboration with African Fellows through the African Economic ResearchConsortium continued with training of 25 researchers on the methods of impactevaluations in 2019. The important work together with Fellows has been continued in 2020 but severalnbactivities have had to be adjusted or postponed during the pandemic due to travel restrictions. An important result in 2019 was the seventh Transfer Project workshop: SocialProtection, Cash Transfers and Long-Term Poverty Reduction, 2-4 April 2019, Arusha, Tanzania. The workshop is an important forum where researchers, government representatives, NGOs and development partners exchange and learn about the use of evaluations and evidence produced by UNICEF Innocenti and partners. This time it was attended by 130 government officials, NGO representatives academics and donors from 20 African nations. The event was disseminated through social media. Sida/ Sweden was represented in the workshop through Josephine Mwangi, social protection programme officer at the Swedish Embassy in Kenya, who gave a brief presentation of the experiences from development of social protection in Kenya. In addition the annual report 2019 includes information on 49 conference presentations, 14 peer reviewed journal articles and nine workshops where the Transfer Project team disseminated evidence to governments and stakeholders. The project is active at international conferences and meetings and at Social Media, Multi-media and Traditional Media. In 2020 old and new methods for vitual meetings and dialogue has been introduced.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
